required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Retrospective Review of Enseal Laparoscopic Vaginal Assisted Hysterectomy (LAVH) Versus Traditional LAVH
clinical_study.official_title: A Retrospective Analysis of a Complete Enseal Laparoscopic Vaginal Assisted Hysterectomy Versus a Traditional Suture Laparoscopic Vaginal Hysterectomy

brief_summary.textblock: Retrospective charts review from one surgeon to compare Group A- cases where the laparoscopic portion of the case used an EN~SEAL device to Group B - the laparoscopic BSO was done using a 3mm EN-SEAL device through 2 lateral 5mm ports.

detailed_description.textblock: 79 women with benign uterine disease underwent laparoscopic assisted vaginal hysterectomy with or without bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. Subjects charts were divided into two groups based on surgical technique and the following parameters were reviewed retrospectively: surgical time, blood loss, uterine weight, patient weight, patient age, post operative fever >100.4 F, readmission to hospital within one week, return to operating room within 24 hours, length of hospital stay, and blood transfusion. Group A, N=35 used traditional suture technique vaginally. Group B, N=44 used Enseal coagulation cutting device vaginally.

primary_outcome.description: The total time the subject spent in surgery was compared between the two groups

primary_outcome.time_frame: Blood loss during surgery in cc per minute
primary_outcome.description: The total blood loss in cc per minutes operating was compared between the two groups

arm_group.description: Women aged 35-75 who underwent laparoscopic assisted vaginal hysterectomy via either suture technique vaginally or Enseal coagulation cutting device vaginally

study_pop.textblock: patients who underwent Laparoscopically Assisted Vaginal Hysterectomy (LAVH)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- none, observational study
Exclusion Criteria:
- none, observational study
